title: ‘Toe Rody’s line or resign’
text:
‘Toe Rody’s line or resign’ By Jess Diaz (The Philippine Star)   
MANILA, Philippines - Cabinet members and other officials who disagree with President Duterte on policy and his statements should resign, Speaker Pantaleon Alvarez said yesterday. 
He told reporters that he recently attended a meeting of several Cabinet members and “I reminded them that they are the alter (egos) of the President” and “they cannot contradict his views.” 
Alvarez said it would be absurd for Duterte and any of his Cabinet officials to have different views on a particular issue. 
Alvarez served as secretary of transportation and communications during the Arroyo administration. 
Asked if he would like to discourage debates between Duterte and his Cabinet officials, he said, “What I am saying is if you cannot agree with him, you keep quiet. Otherwise, you are free to resign and tell him he is wrong.” 
He said he had no particular Cabinet member in mind in making his appeal.   
He made the call in the course of discussing his proposal to reduce the age of criminal responsibility from 15 to nine years old. 
“I was still in college studying law, that was already nine years. Society has advanced tremendously since then in terms of discernment, so it should be brought back to nine years,” he said. 
Leftist Cabinet members, including Judy Taguiwalo of social welfare and development, are reportedly against lowering the age of criminal responsibility, which Duterte, like Alvarez, has advocated. 
Asked if he has discussed his call on Cabinet members with the President, the Speaker said he did not have to because that was only what he felt about how they should conduct themselves. 
He reminded them that they would be made to account for their actions when they appear before lawmakers in the future to defend their agencies’ proposed budgets. 
Duterte has publicly criticized at least one Cabinet member, Transportation Secretary Arthur Tugade. 
The President said he has not seen improvement in Metro Manila traffic, and in the lack of vehicle license plates and driver’s license.
